metadata.case_name: Jyoti Bhushan Gupta & Anr. v. Official Liquidator, Banaras Bank Ltd.

facts.text: Banaras Bank Ltd., a public limited company with registered office at Banaras, ordered to be compulsorily wound up by High Court of Judicature at Allahabad on March 1, 1940; Official Liquidator appointed.

On September 12, 1942, High Court under s.187 Indian Companies Act, 1913 ordered appellants Jyoti Bhushan Gupta and Gokul Chand, on list of contributories, to pay Rs. 95,178/5/9 with interest to Official Liquidator.
Order enforceable as decree of High Court per s.199 of Companies Act.
On September 12, 1946, order transferred to District Judge, Allahabad for execution.
On September 23, 1946, Official Liquidator applied to District Court, Allahabad for execution and attachment of amounts due to appellants.
Execution proceedings transferred to Civil Judge, Allahabad.
Appellants contended execution application barred by limitation under Art. 182 (3 years from order).
Official Liquidator contended governed by Art. 183 (12 years); alternatively, part payments extended limitation (plea later abandoned).
Civil Judge held application barred by limitation.
High Court in Execution First Appeal No. 399 of 1947 reversed Civil Judge's order on August 24, 1950, remitted proceedings to Civil Judge.
Appeal to Supreme Court with certificate under Art. 133 Constitution.
No notification empowering District Court at Banaras under proviso to s.3 Companies Act.

legal_issues.text: Whether execution application governed by Art. 182 (3 years) or Art. 183 (12 years) of Limitation Act.
Whether High Court order under s.187 Companies Act passed in exercise of ordinary original civil jurisdiction.

petitioner_arguments.text: Execution application barred by Art. 182 as not preferred within 3 years; order not under Art. 183 as High Court not exercising ordinary original civil jurisdiction under Letters Patent; special power under s.187 in extraordinary jurisdiction.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Art. 182 Limitation Act; Letters Patent Allahabad High Court; s.187 Companies Act 1913

petitioner_arguments.text: Allahabad High Court not invested with ordinary original civil jurisdiction like Presidency High Courts.

respondent_arguments.text: Application governed by Art. 183 (12 years) as order passed in ordinary original civil jurisdiction.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Art. 183 Limitation Act; s.187, s.3 Companies Act 1913

court_reasoning.text: Jurisdiction under s.187 is ordinary (exercisable as of right, no extraordinary action), original (court of first instance), civil (adjudicates debt liability); summary proceeding does not alter character.
court_reasoning.key_observation: High Court only competent court per s.3 Companies Act.

court_reasoning.text: Art. 183 applies to orders in ordinary original civil jurisdiction; jurisdiction conferred by later legislation like Companies Act is ordinary original civil if as court of first instance without discretion.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Distinguishes from extraordinary jurisdiction requiring special steps.

court_reasoning.text: Appeal maintainable on merits despite preliminary objection.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Court heard on merits due to importance.

holdings.text: Order under s.187 passed in exercise of ordinary original civil jurisdiction; execution governed by Art. 183 Limitation Act (12 years).

precedents_cited.case_name: In the matter of Candas Narondas Navivahu and C.A. Turner
precedents_cited.relevance: Insolvency jurisdiction of High Court is ordinary original civil jurisdiction for Limitation Act Art. 183 equivalent.

precedents_cited.case_name: P.T. Munia Servai v. The Hanuman Bank Ltd., Tanjore
precedents_cited.relevance: Order under Banking Companies Act by High Court in winding up is ordinary original civil jurisdiction under Art. 183.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Companies Act, 1913
statutes_cited.relevance: Confers jurisdiction on High Court for winding up orders enforceable as decrees; s.187 for payment by contributories.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Limitation Act, 1908
statutes_cited.relevance: Art. 182: 3 years for execution unless Art. 183; Art. 183: 12 years for High Court ordinary original civil jurisdiction.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Certificate for appeal to Supreme Court.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court dismissed the appeal, holding the execution application within limitation under Art. 183; affirmed High Court order remitting proceedings.

key_quotes.text: "The jurisdiction is ordinary it does number depend on any extraordinary action on the part of the High Court. The jurisdiction is also original in character because the petition for exercise of the jurisdiction is entertainable by the High Court as a companyrt of first instance"
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Defines character of s.187 jurisdiction as ordinary original civil.

key_quotes.text: "their Lordships are of the opinion that the expression ordinary jurisdiction embraces all such as is exercised in the ordinary companyrse of law and without any special step being necessary to assume it"
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Quotes Privy Council on ordinary vs extraordinary jurisdiction.
